output.conclusion: By completing this course, you've gained a solid understanding of explainable recommendations, equipping you to build more transparent and trustworthy recommendation systems. You can now apply these techniques to improve user trust and satisfaction in your own projects.
output.introduction: This course provides an intermediate-level introduction to explainable recommendations. We will explore various techniques for making recommendation systems more transparent and understandable to users, focusing on practical applications and real-world examples.

chapters.description: Brief overview of XAI principles and its importance in machine learning. Discuss the need for transparency and trust in AI systems.
Why explainability is crucial in recommendation systems. Discuss the benefits of explainable recommendations for users and businesses.
Different types of explanations: textual, visual, and example-based. Discuss the pros and cons of each type.
Generating explanations based on association rules. Example: 'Users who bought X also bought Y because of rule Z'.
Explaining recommendations based on item features. Example: 'Recommended because it shares similar features with items you liked before'.
Explaining recommendations based on similar users' preferences. Example: 'Recommended because users similar to you also liked this item'.
Applying explanation techniques to existing 'black box' recommendation models. LIME and SHAP for recommendation systems.
Using attention weights in neural networks to highlight important features for recommendations.
Leveraging knowledge graphs to provide richer and more contextual explanations.
Metrics for evaluating the quality of explanations: accuracy, comprehensibility, and satisfaction.
Designing and conducting user studies to assess the impact of explainable recommendations on user trust and engagement.
Addressing potential biases and ethical concerns in explainable recommendation systems.
